Comments_List: I learned to be more critical about development programs and how they may reinforce existing gender disparities.

Through this course I learned how women issues are approached by the development discourse and actors and the implications/effects/consequences of this approach. We analyzed different types of papers (from academic to policy reports), and discussed them. I developed analysis skills and expanded my knowledge on development theory, gender-related issues, and cases around the world.
We covered a good range of material, and the professors facilitated discussion well.

I really enjoyed the class modules and the weekly themes. The format of the class allowed me to learned from the instructors and classmates. They bring different perspectives to class discussions and that was very interesting for me. However, I would have liked to have different activities during the sessions because the structure of the class was often the same. I remembered the class when we had a guest speaker who share her experience and the work she is doing with us. I really enjoyed this session. Also, I would have liked to learn more about the experience of the professors as they are doing interesting research and work.
A good class that teaches you to be more critical about development programs and how they may reinforce existing gender disparities.

Yes! but I highly recommend to taken when students have a background on social sciences or have taken seminar courses before. For me the course was very challenging as it was the first time I was exposed to readings and terminology on anthropology as well as to seminar-style discussions. I took a lot from the course, I really enjoyed learning from the other students, but I barely participated as I did not feel at the same level of them.
